sentence: Can you lease to own value with Home Depot?
Home Depot is the world's largest home improvement retailer with over 2,250 stores and $70 billion in revenues.
An average store has over 30,000 items with everything you needed to remodel a home including the kitchen sink.
The company's stock has done well over the last two years rising from $35 a share up to $75.48.
Sales have been growing at 6.2% in FY 2013 but are expected to slow to 4.9% growth in FY2014.
The company's sales generally break down into plumbing, electrical and kitchen (31%); hardware (29%); lumber (21%); and flooring and paint (19%).
Earnings per share have also been doing well growing from 1.37 a share in 2009 up to 3.00 a share in 2013.
Analysts expect HD will be able to pull in 3.70 a share in 2014 and will be watching the earnings release this week in Q3 of FY2014 when company is expected to report about 0.88 a share.
Home Depot has been doing well, but there are some storm clouds on the horizon.
The stock may be fairly valued at this point as S&P has a two STARS sell recommendation on HD based on valuation.
In 2014, there are only 52 weeks in the year as opposed to the 53 weeks tallied in 2013.
Analysts realize this, but it will make total sales grow at a slower rate in FY 2014.
While Home Depot sells to the do it yourself and the professional market, home improvement can be heavily dependent on interest rates.
We all remember the sub-prime housing crisis of a few years ago and know that interest rates affect the amount of money homeowners can borrow.
When interest rates are low people can borrow lots of money, but as rates rise people will borrow less.
Interest rates are so low now they have to rise, but people have fear of what will happen when the Fed starts to turn off the spigot which has been flooding markets with cheap money.
Fears of higher interest rates having a significant effect may be overblown as well.
People will still want to update old homes and build new ones as interest rates rise.
HD has done remarkable job through a multi-year housing slowdown and while interest rates affect new construction and big building projects, they have varied widely over the last 35 years.
Interest rates can go up significantly and still be below average.
Husbands everywhere will still have wives asking them to repaint living rooms when interest rates are several points higher.
Since HD stock has been doing well long term, it is the type of stock that you might want to add to a portfolio.
Since the stock could see some short term headwinds, near term expectations should be kept in check.
One could well buy the stock and then turn around and sell the covered call pulling in a little extra premium over the short term.
This would be a strategic move to capitalize on both long term performance and short term headwinds.
Entering a buy-write on the February 77.50 covered call would cost 74.55 (77.60-3.05).
One would buy the stock and sell the call in one transaction at the same time.
The call has a simple assigned return rate of 4.0% over the next 100 days or a 14% annualized return rate (for comparison purposes only).
The trade has 3.9% of downside protection built in.
This would sort of be like buying a house and leasing it out to a tenant, but giving them the right to buy it at a set price during the lease.
Sometimes called lease-to-own or rent-to-own transaction, this type of deal can benefit both the buyer and seller if done properly and at the right price.
A seller can be happy to sell the house because they will make money if they do, but they also are happy to rent a home because they also will make money if they do.
This situation is typically a win-win for the owner, as long as something bad -like termites or fires- doesn't happen to the house.
It can also be a good situation for a tenant, who may want to buy, but has other circumstances -like a lack of cash or changing job situation- to take into account.
Although a stock and house are two different types of assets, selling a call brings in extra cash and reduces the holding cost.
Covered calls have the risk that the underlying stock can fall in price, but if one selects good stocks -like selecting the right type of house in the right neighborhoods- this risk in minimized.
Strategically using covered calls can allow one to profit based on a variety of circumstances and other trends taking place in the market.
